... more Photo: File/Google Giant hole on I-45 near Hardy Toll Road may not be fixed by rush hour 1 / 5 Back to Gallery Motorists on the North Freeway are suffering heavy delays after a section of road eroded creating a giant hole on the northbound lanes Wednesday morning.
Transportation officials, meanwhile, are unsure if repairs can be completed on the 7-foot by 10-foot section of the freeway by the evening commute, when northbound traffic is far heavier than in the morning.
The Texas Department of Transportation reported the incident about 5:40 a.m. and says it's affecting the left lane and a center lane near the interchange with the Hardy Toll Road and the Grand Parkway.
Northbound traffic backed up over 5 miles, nearly reaching the Richey exit, Houston TranStar cameras showed about 8:30 a.m.
You can see Spring Creek flowing below I-45 N through the massive pothole that opened up just north of the Hardy Toll Road.
Media: MediaOS Video The highway pavement appears to have fallen directly into Spring Creek flowing under the road, exposing a web of rebar that will take a while to repair.
"This is not just a patch, it is going to take some time," TxDOT spokesman Danny Perez said. "It is going to be hours."
Crews will perform a saw-cut in the pavement, removing all of the steel and concrete in a rectangular area around what is essentially a hole in the bridge. It does not affect the integrity of the overpass, Perez said.
But it does, however, take time to repair. Crews will cut until they have a sufficient area to remove all the damage, then reattach new rebar and pour concrete.
"We want to address it before the evening rush," Perez said. "Once they do the cutting and get the concrete out they'll know if that's possible."
Crews typically scout for potholes and other problems on highways and then schedule repairs for overnight periods when there is less traffic. Perez said this problem likely developed quickly overnight, and TxDOT simply couldn't wait.
"Once it starts to fail, you have multiple vehicles and it just grows," he said.
Check back later for more updates to this developing story.
